questions.question: For calendar-year individual taxpayers, the due date for filing Form 1040 is:

options.A: March 15
options.B: April 15
options.C: June 15

questions.explanation: Individual income tax returns (Form 1040) are due on the 15th day of the 4th month following the close of the tax year. For calendar-year taxpayers, this is April 15. If the date falls on a weekend or holiday, the due date is extended to the next business day.
questions.tip: Individual = April 15. C Corps = April 15. S Corps and Partnerships = March 15. These are the key dates.

questions.question: Filing Form 4868 provides an automatic extension for individual taxpayers of:

options.A: 3 months
options.B: 4 months
options.C: 6 months

questions.explanation: Form 4868 provides an automatic 6-month extension to file an individual tax return, extending the due date from April 15 to October 15. The extension is for filing only—it does not extend the time to pay. Tax is still due by April 15 to avoid penalties and interest.
questions.tip: Extension to file ≠ extension to pay. Pay by April 15 to avoid failure-to-pay penalty and interest.

questions.question: The general statute of limitations for the IRS to assess additional tax is:

options.A: 2 years from filing
options.B: 3 years from filing or due date, whichever is later
options.C: 5 years from filing

questions.explanation: The general statute of limitations for assessment is 3 years from the later of the filing date or the due date. If a return is filed early, the 3-year period begins on the due date. This period can be extended under certain circumstances such as substantial understatements or fraud.
questions.tip: General rule = 3 years. Extended to 6 years if >25% gross income omission. No limit for fraud or failure to file.

questions.question: The failure-to-file penalty is generally:

options.A: 0.5% of unpaid tax per month, up to 25%
options.B: 5% of unpaid tax per month, up to 25%
options.C: 10% of unpaid tax per month, up to 50%

questions.explanation: The failure-to-file penalty is 5% of unpaid tax per month or part of a month, up to a maximum of 25%. The failure-to-pay penalty is 0.5% per month, also up to 25%. When both apply, the failure-to-file penalty is reduced by the failure-to-pay amount.
questions.tip: 5% to file, 0.5% to pay. Filing late is more expensive than paying late—file on time even if you can't pay!

questions.question: For calendar-year individual taxpayers, the due dates for estimated tax payments are:

options.A: January 15, April 15, July 15, October 15
options.B: March 15, June 15, September 15, December 15
options.C: April 15, June 15, September 15, January 15

questions.explanation: Estimated tax payments are due on April 15, June 15, September 15, and January 15 of the following year. Note that the second quarter payment is due June 15 (2 months after Q1), not July 15. The fourth payment is due January 15 of the next year.
questions.tip: April, June, September, January—the June date is only 2 months after April, which often trips people up.

questions.question: To petition the U.S. Tax Court, a taxpayer must:

options.A: First pay the disputed tax in full
options.B: Have received a notice of deficiency
options.C: Have income above a certain threshold

questions.explanation: The Tax Court is a prepayment forum—taxpayers can challenge a deficiency without paying the disputed tax first. However, the IRS must have issued a notice of deficiency (90-day letter) before a petition can be filed. The petition must be filed within 90 days of the notice.
questions.tip: Tax Court = no prepayment required. District Court or Court of Federal Claims = must pay first, then sue for refund.

questions.question: The accuracy-related penalty for a substantial understatement of income tax is:

options.A: 10% of the understatement
options.B: 20% of the understatement
options.C: 50% of the understatement

questions.explanation: The accuracy-related penalty under Section 6662 is 20% and applies to underpayments due to negligence, disregard of rules, substantial understatement, substantial valuation misstatement, and other specified causes. A substantial understatement exists when the understatement exceeds the greater of 10% of the correct tax or $5,000.
questions.tip: 20% for accuracy-related issues, 75% for civil fraud. Know the 10%/$5,000 threshold for substantial understatement.

questions.question: The statute of limitations is extended to 6 years when:

options.A: Any amount of income is omitted
options.B: Gross income is understated by more than 25%
options.C: The taxpayer files an amended return
options.D: The IRS issues a notice of deficiency

questions.explanation: The 6-year statute of limitations applies when there is an omission of gross income exceeding 25% of the gross income stated on the return. For trade or business, this includes omissions of amounts over 25% of gross receipts. The extended period provides the IRS more time to discover substantial omissions.
questions.tip: 25% = 6 years. Fraud or failure to file = unlimited. Remember that overstated deductions don't trigger 6 years.

questions.question: The IRS Discriminant Function System (DIF) is used to:

options.A: Determine the amount of penalty to assess
options.B: Score returns for audit potential based on probable tax change
options.C: Calculate the statute of limitations period
options.D: Match information returns to tax returns

questions.explanation: The DIF system assigns scores to returns based on the probability that an audit would result in a tax change. Returns with higher DIF scores are more likely to be selected for examination. The system uses statistical models based on past audit results to identify returns with potential issues.
questions.tip: DIF is the primary computer screening method. Other methods include informant tips, related returns, and information matching.

questions.question: A taxpayer who disagrees with the results of an IRS examination may request a conference with the IRS Appeals Office by:

options.A: Filing a petition in Tax Court
options.B: Filing a formal written protest for proposed adjustments over $25,000
options.C: Calling the IRS hotline within 30 days

questions.explanation: For proposed adjustments exceeding $25,000, a formal written protest is required to appeal. For smaller amounts, a small case request or brief written statement may be sufficient. The Appeals Office is independent of the examination function and has authority to settle cases based on hazards of litigation.
questions.tip: Over $25,000 = formal protest required. Under $25,000 = small case request acceptable.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to constitute reasonable cause for waiver of the failure-to-file penalty?

options.A: Ignorance of the tax law
options.B: Reliance on incorrect advice from a competent tax professional
options.C: Lack of funds to pay the tax due
options.D: Heavy work schedule during tax season

questions.explanation: Reasonable cause may be established when a taxpayer exercises ordinary business care and prudence but still fails to comply. Reliance on professional advice (if the taxpayer provided complete information) can demonstrate reasonable cause. Ignorance of law, lack of funds, and busy schedules generally do not excuse filing failures.
questions.tip: Reasonable cause = ordinary care but still couldn't comply. Document your due diligence and professional reliance.

questions.question: Interest on tax underpayments:

options.A: Is deductible as a business expense
options.B: Runs from the due date of the return until paid
options.C: Can be waived for reasonable cause
options.D: Is charged only if penalties also apply

questions.explanation: Interest on underpayments runs from the due date of the return (without regard to extensions) until payment is received. Unlike penalties, interest cannot be waived or abated for reasonable cause. Interest is charged on the unpaid tax plus any penalties. Personal tax interest is not deductible.
questions.tip: Interest cannot be waived—penalties can. Interest runs from original due date, not extended due date.

questions.question: An individual taxpayer can avoid the estimated tax underpayment penalty by paying at least:

options.A: 80% of the current year tax liability
options.B: 90% of the current year tax liability or 100% of prior year tax
options.C: 100% of the current year tax liability
options.D: The amount withheld in the prior year

questions.explanation: The safe harbor requires paying at least 90% of the current year tax or 100% of the prior year tax (110% if prior year AGI exceeded $150,000). Meeting either test avoids the underpayment penalty. The prior year safe harbor provides certainty since it's based on a known amount.
questions.tip: 90% current OR 100% prior (110% if AGI > $150K). Prior year safe harbor is useful when income is unpredictable.

questions.question: A claim for refund must generally be filed within:

options.A: 2 years from the date the tax was paid
options.B: 3 years from filing the return or 2 years from payment, whichever is later
options.C: 5 years from the due date of the return
options.D: The same period as the assessment statute of limitations

questions.explanation: The refund statute of limitations is the later of 3 years from the date the return was filed or 2 years from the date the tax was paid. If the claim is filed within 3 years, the refund is limited to the amount paid within 3 years of the claim plus the extension period.
questions.tip: 3 years from filing OR 2 years from payment, whichever is later. The refund amount may be limited.

questions.question: An individual taxpayer discovers an error on a 2021 return filed on April 15, 2022. The latest date to file an amended return claiming a refund is:

options.A: April 15, 2024
options.B: April 15, 2025
options.C: April 15, 2026
options.D: There is no time limit for amended returns

questions.explanation: To claim a refund, an amended return must be filed within 3 years from the date the original return was filed. The original return was filed April 15, 2022, so the amended return must be filed by April 15, 2025. If only a correction (no refund) is needed, there's no specific deadline.
questions.tip: Amended return for refund = 3 years from original filing date. No refund possible after that date.

questions.question: Upon receiving a statutory notice of deficiency (90-day letter), a taxpayer has how many days to petition the Tax Court?

options.A: 30 days
options.B: 60 days
options.C: 90 days

questions.explanation: A taxpayer has 90 days from the date of the notice of deficiency to petition the Tax Court (150 days if the notice is addressed to a person outside the United States). If no petition is filed, the deficiency becomes final and the IRS can assess and collect the tax.
questions.tip: 90 days is jurisdictional—missing it means no Tax Court. Outside U.S. = 150 days.

questions.question: When both failure-to-file and failure-to-pay penalties apply for the same month, the combined penalty rate is:

options.A: 0.5% per month
options.B: 5% per month
options.C: 5.5% per month

questions.explanation: When both penalties apply, the failure-to-file penalty (5%) is reduced by the failure-to-pay penalty (0.5%), resulting in a net failure-to-file of 4.5%. Combined with the 0.5% failure-to-pay, the total is 5% per month. This prevents double-counting the failure-to-pay component.
questions.tip: 5% - 0.5% + 0.5% = 5% total. The failure-to-file penalty is reduced by the failure-to-pay amount when both apply.

questions.question: The IRS generally has how long to collect a tax after assessment?

options.A: 3 years
options.B: 6 years
options.C: 10 years

questions.explanation: The collection statute of limitations is 10 years from the date of assessment. This period can be extended by agreement or suspended for bankruptcy, offer in compromise, or collection due process hearing. After 10 years, the liability is extinguished and the IRS cannot pursue collection.
questions.tip: Assessment = 3 years. Collection = 10 years. Fraud = unlimited for assessment, but collection still 10 years.

questions.question: A business must issue Form 1099-NEC for payments to an independent contractor when total payments during the year equal or exceed:
questions.explanation: Form 1099-NEC must be issued for nonemployee compensation of $600 or more paid to an individual who is not an employee. This applies to payments for services, not for merchandise. Payments to corporations generally don't require 1099s (with exceptions for legal and medical services).
questions.tip: $600 threshold for 1099-NEC. Must be filed by January 31—no extension available.

questions.question: Which form authorizes a representative to practice before the IRS on behalf of a taxpayer?

options.A: Form 2848
options.B: Form 8821
options.C: Form 4868

questions.explanation: Form 2848, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative, authorizes an individual to represent a taxpayer before the IRS. Form 8821 only authorizes the IRS to disclose tax information but does not grant representation rights. The representative must be eligible to practice before the IRS.
questions.tip: Form 2848 = POA with representation. Form 8821 = information disclosure only, no representation authority.

questions.question: Under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights, taxpayers have the right to:

options.A: Demand an IRS employee be terminated
options.B: Refuse to pay any disputed tax
options.C: Know the maximum amount of time to respond to an IRS request
options.D: Have all tax liabilities discharged after 5 years

questions.explanation: The Taxpayer Bill of Rights includes the right to be informed, which means knowing what they need to do to comply and understanding deadlines for responding to IRS requests. Other rights include quality service, paying no more than correct tax, challenging the IRS, and finality.
questions.tip: Know the 10 taxpayer rights: informed, quality service, pay only what's owed, challenge, appeal, finality, privacy, confidentiality, retain representation, and fair tax system.

questions.question: The civil fraud penalty is:

options.A: 20% of the underpayment
options.B: 50% of the underpayment
options.C: 75% of the underpayment due to fraud

questions.explanation: The civil fraud penalty is 75% of the portion of the underpayment attributable to fraud. Unlike the accuracy-related penalty (20%), the fraud penalty requires the IRS to prove fraud by clear and convincing evidence. The fraud penalty replaces (not stacks with) the accuracy-related penalty for the fraudulent portion.
questions.tip: 75% fraud penalty replaces 20% accuracy penalty for the fraudulent portion. IRS has burden of proof.

questions.question: The federally authorized tax practitioner privilege under Section 7525:

options.A: Is identical to attorney-client privilege in all respects
options.B: Applies to communications regarding tax advice in noncriminal tax matters before the IRS
options.C: Covers all communications between any CPA and client
options.D: Cannot be waived by the client

questions.explanation: Section 7525 extends privilege to tax advice communications between taxpayers and federally authorized tax practitioners (CPAs, enrolled agents, attorneys) in noncriminal IRS proceedings and Tax Court. It does not apply to criminal matters, state tax issues, or written tax shelter advice. The privilege is narrower than attorney-client privilege.
questions.tip: Section 7525: noncriminal, federal tax, non-shelter advice only. Does NOT apply to criminal investigations or tax shelters.

questions.question: An offer in compromise (OIC) may be accepted by the IRS when:

options.A: The taxpayer simply cannot afford to pay the full amount
options.B: There is doubt as to collectibility or doubt as to liability
options.C: The taxpayer requests a payment plan

questions.explanation: The IRS may accept an OIC based on: doubt as to collectibility (taxpayer's assets and income are insufficient), doubt as to liability (genuine dispute about the correct tax), or effective tax administration (exceptional circumstances where collection would create economic hardship or be unfair). Simply being unable to pay isn't sufficient.
questions.tip: OIC bases: doubt as to liability, doubt as to collectibility, or effective tax administration (ETA).

questions.question: A taxpayer can avoid the substantial understatement penalty if the position has:

options.A: A reasonable basis and is disclosed on the return
options.B: Substantial authority or is disclosed with reasonable basis
options.C: Any colorable support in the tax law
options.D: Been approved by the IRS in a prior audit

questions.explanation: The substantial understatement penalty can be avoided if: (1) the position has substantial authority (more likely than not to be sustained), or (2) the position has at least a reasonable basis (realistic possibility) AND is adequately disclosed on Form 8275. For tax shelters, stricter rules apply.
questions.tip: Substantial authority = ~40% chance of success. Reasonable basis = ~20% chance. Disclosure helps only with reasonable basis positions.

questions.question: A taxpayer who wants a jury trial for a tax dispute must file suit in:

options.A: U.S. Tax Court
options.B: U.S. District Court
options.C: U.S. Court of Federal Claims
options.D: Any of the above at taxpayer's election

questions.explanation: The U.S. District Court is the only trial court for tax matters that provides a right to jury trial. The Tax Court and Court of Federal Claims do not offer jury trials. District Court and Court of Federal Claims require prepayment of the disputed tax (refund suit), while Tax Court does not.
questions.tip: Jury trial = District Court only. No prepayment = Tax Court. All three use different appellate routes.

questions.question: In a Tax Court proceeding, the burden of proof shifts to the IRS when the taxpayer:

options.A: Files a timely petition
options.B: Introduces credible evidence and meets substantiation requirements
options.C: Disputes any IRS adjustment

questions.explanation: Under Section 7491, the burden of proof shifts to the IRS in court proceedings if the taxpayer introduces credible evidence, maintains adequate records, cooperates with reasonable IRS requests, and meets any applicable substantiation requirements. This applies only to factual issues, not legal interpretations.
questions.tip: Burden shift requires: credible evidence, records, cooperation, and substantiation. Only for factual issues in court.

questions.question: A Collection Due Process (CDP) hearing provides the taxpayer the opportunity to:

options.A: Appeal only to IRS Appeals
options.B: Challenge the underlying liability and propose collection alternatives
options.C: Automatically stay collection for 2 years
options.D: Request that the IRS forgive all penalties

questions.explanation: A CDP hearing allows the taxpayer to challenge the underlying liability (if not previously contested), propose collection alternatives (installment agreement, OIC), and challenge the appropriateness of the collection action. Following the hearing, the taxpayer may appeal to Tax Court within 30 days of the determination.
questions.tip: CDP hearing: challenge liability (if first opportunity), propose alternatives, get judicial review in Tax Court.

questions.question: To qualify for innocent spouse relief under Section 6015(b), the requesting spouse must show:

options.A: That they are now divorced from the other spouse
options.B: That they did not know and had no reason to know of the understatement
options.C: That they earned less income than the other spouse
options.D: That the understatement was due to a math error

questions.explanation: Traditional innocent spouse relief requires: (1) joint return filed, (2) understatement attributable to erroneous items of the other spouse, (3) the requesting spouse did not know and had no reason to know of the understatement, and (4) it would be inequitable to hold the requesting spouse liable. Alternative relief options exist under 6015(c) and (f).
questions.tip: Innocent spouse: joint return, other spouse's error, didn't know, inequitable to hold liable. Separation of liability is an alternative.

questions.question: The crime of tax evasion under Section 7201 requires proof of:

options.A: Any tax underpayment
options.B: Willfulness and an affirmative act of evasion
options.C: Negligence in preparing the return

questions.explanation: Tax evasion requires: (1) an additional tax is due, (2) the taxpayer committed an affirmative act of evasion (concealment of assets, false entries, etc.), and (3) willfulness (intentional violation of a known legal duty). The government must prove each element beyond a reasonable doubt.
questions.tip: Tax evasion = willful + affirmative act. Tax fraud = no affirmative act required. Criminal = beyond reasonable doubt.

questions.question: A federal tax lien arises:

options.A: When the IRS files Form 668(Y) with the county recorder
options.B: When assessment is made and notice and demand is given and the taxpayer fails to pay
options.C: Only when the taxpayer's assets exceed the amount owed
options.D: 60 days after a notice of deficiency is issued

questions.explanation: A federal tax lien arises automatically when: (1) a tax is assessed, (2) notice and demand for payment is sent, and (3) the taxpayer neglects or refuses to pay. The lien attaches to all property and rights to property. Filing the Notice of Federal Tax Lien (Form 668) makes the lien public but is not required for the lien to exist.
questions.tip: Lien arises automatically (assess, demand, nonpayment). Filing just makes it public for priority purposes.

questions.question: The IRS first-time abatement (FTA) policy applies when:

options.A: The taxpayer has no prior penalties in the last 3 years and is in compliance
options.B: The taxpayer requests abatement in writing with supporting documentation
options.C: The penalty amount is under $1,000
options.D: The taxpayer files an amended return correcting the error

questions.explanation: First-time abatement is an administrative waiver for failure-to-file or failure-to-pay penalties if the taxpayer has: (1) no penalties for the prior 3 tax years, (2) filed all required returns or extensions, and (3) paid or arranged to pay any taxes due. It's a relief valve for otherwise compliant taxpayers.
questions.tip: FTA: clean 3-year history, all returns filed, all taxes paid. Available by phone—no formal request needed.

questions.question: The assessment statute of limitations is suspended during:

options.A: Any period when the taxpayer is outside the U.S. for more than 60 days
options.B: The 90-day period after mailing a notice of deficiency
options.C: The time the taxpayer's CPA is unavailable

questions.explanation: The assessment statute is suspended during the 90-day period (150 days if outside U.S.) for the taxpayer to petition the Tax Court, plus 60 additional days. It's also suspended during bankruptcy and while an offer in compromise is pending. The suspension ensures the IRS has adequate time after restrictions are lifted.
questions.tip: Statute suspended during: Tax Court petition period, bankruptcy, OIC pending, and certain asset concealment situations.

questions.question: A tax return preparer is subject to a penalty for an unreasonable position unless:

options.A: The position has any support in the tax law
options.B: The position has substantial authority or is disclosed with a reasonable basis
options.C: The preparer is a CPA in good standing
options.D: The client insists on taking the position

questions.explanation: Under Section 6694(a), a preparer faces a penalty for an undisclosed position unless it has substantial authority, or for a disclosed position unless it has a reasonable basis. The penalty is the greater of $1,000 or 50% of preparer's fee. Willful or reckless positions carry a higher penalty under 6694(b).
questions.tip: Preparer standards: substantial authority undisclosed, reasonable basis disclosed. Higher than taxpayer standards.

questions.question: Under the substance-over-form doctrine, the IRS may:

options.A: Recharacterize a transaction based on its economic substance rather than its legal form
options.B: Impose penalties without issuing a notice
options.C: Extend the statute of limitations indefinitely

questions.explanation: Substance over form allows the IRS to look through the legal form of a transaction to its underlying economic substance and tax it accordingly. Related doctrines include the step transaction doctrine (treating multiple steps as one), business purpose (transactions must have non-tax purpose), and economic substance (must change economic position).
questions.tip: Substance over form, step transaction, business purpose, and economic substance are all judicial anti-abuse doctrines.
